articles.author: Liam
articles.description:
The Maze Game is a client-side experience driven by QR code scanning, localStorage, and conditional UI flows. Here's a breakdown of its key components and logic:
QR Code Entry (/maze-game/[code])



Users scan a QR code that opens a route with a unique code param.
On page load:
The [code] is added to localStorage.foundCodes if itâ€™s not already present.
Displays a confirmation (e.g., name and image).
After a short delay, user is redirected to /maze-game.
Game Dashboard (/maze-game)




On load:
Retrieves foundCodes and submissions from localStorage.
Fetches the current seasonâ€™s valid codes from the server.
Compares:
Filters local codes to include only those valid for the current season.
If all season codes are found:
Checks if the current year is in localStorage.submissions.
If not, displays the submission form.
Submission Flow




On form submission:
Sends user details via an email API.
Records the current year in localStorage.submissions to prevent repeat entries.
Storage Format





// localStorage.foundCodes = ["alpha", "bravo", "charlie"]
// localStorage.submissions = ["2024"]

Persistence Notes




localStorage is used for persistence across page reloads and sessions.
There is no backend account system; uniqueness is enforced by year-based checks.
articles.title: Maze Game - finally on the web

articles.author: Michael Ikoko
articles.description:
Introduction


After blinking your first LED on Arduino, what's next? Before moving on to more complex concepts, you can design a real-world application for controlling LEDs using a microcontroller by simulating traffic lights. 
This is a beginner-friendly tutorial on simulating traffic lights  using Arduino. It also adds complexity by including a countdown timer using a 7-segment display.
At the end of the tutorial, you will be able to control three LEDs to mimic traffic lights. Additionally, you will have an understanding of what a 7-segment display is and how to program it with a microcontroller.
This article makes use of the Wokwi simulator for designing. The same design concepts can be applied to any other microcontroller simulator of your choice, like Tinkercad or Fritzing. If you haâ€¦
articles.title: Building a Traffic Light Simulator with a Countdown using Arduino and a 7-Segment Display

articles.author: Isaac Bokhoor
articles.description:
Ever get so deep into what you're doing that the world just blurs out? Hours disappear. Distractions fade. All thatâ€™s left is you and the work.
Thatâ€™s the flow stateâ€”and itâ€™s something I chase every time I pick up a tattoo machine.
Iâ€™ve found that tattooing, much like writing code or designing an interface, demands full presence. Thereâ€™s no Ctrl+Z. No clean undo. Just real-time decisions, trust in your skills, and a commitment to keep moving. Itâ€™s meditative and intense at the same time.
Hereâ€™s what helps me get into flow:
What I love most? That same feeling shows up across disciplines. Iâ€™ve seen devs drop into it while debugging, designers get lost building UI, and chefs in their rhythm plating dishes.
Different tools. Same human drive.
So wherever you areâ€”keyboard or tattoo machine, canvas or codeâ€”protect your flow. Thatâ€™s where the magic happens.
â€” Isaac Bokhoor
articles.title: The Flow State of Tattooing (and Why Creatives Chase It)

articles.author: Isaac Bokhoor
articles.description:
Iâ€™ve always believed tattooing is more than just body art. Itâ€™s a languageâ€”one that combines structure, emotion, precision, and design. The more I reflect on my work, the more I notice how much tattooing mirrors the process of coding.
Both require:
Clear communication
A strong foundation before layering on complexity
Attention to detail
Respect for the end user (or in my case, the client)
In tattooing, every line matters. Every piece must flow with the body, just like good code flows with logic and user experience. There's room for creativity, but also disciplineâ€”just like in dev work.
Whether Iâ€™m sketching full sleeves or crafting micro-details, I see tattooing as visual problem-solving. My goal is always to translate someoneâ€™s story or idea into a lasting, wearable designâ€”something functional, aesthetic, and deeply personal.
If you're a developer, designer, or builder of any kind: you're a tattoo artist too in your own way. We all leave marksâ€”some visible, some digitalâ€”but all meaningful.
Letâ€™s keep creating with intention.
â€” Isaac Bokhoor
articles.title: Tattooing Is a Creative Language â€” Just Like Code
